definition: adjective: markedly different from an accepted norm
example: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.
translations: adj. 异常的；畸变的；脱离常轨的；迷乱的

definition: noun: a deviation from what is normal or expected
example: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.
translations: n. 失常；离开正路，越轨

definition: verb: formally reject or give up (as a belief)
example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.
translations: vt. 发誓放弃；公开放弃；避免

definition: adjective: open and honest
example: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard – some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.
translations: adv. 光明正大地；率直地
adj. 光明正大的；直率的

definition: verb: revoke formally
example: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.
translations: vt. 废除；取消

definition: verb: choose not to consume or take part in (particularly something enjoyable)
example: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar--even chocolate.
translations: vi. 自制；放弃；避免

definition: adjective: difficult to understand; incomprehensible
example: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.
translations: adj. 深奥的；难懂的

definition: adjective: extremely bad
example: Coach Ramsey took his newest player off the field after watching a few painful minutes of her abysmal performance.
translations: adj. 深不可测的；糟透的；极度的

definition: noun: the ability to go into (when somebody or something must allow you to enter)
verb: to go into something when allowed to enter
example: Only students have access to the university library.
There is a large amount of oil under the ice, but we have not be able to access it.
translations: vt. 使用；存取；接近
n. 进入；使用权；通路

definition: noun: an award or praise granted as a special honor
example: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.
translations: n. 荣誉；荣誉称号授予仪式；连谱号；称赞

definition: adjective: harsh in tone
example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.
translations: adj. 尖刻的（等于acerb）；酸的；辛辣的

definition: noun: the highest point of achievement
example: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.
translations: n. 顶点，极点；最高点

definition: noun: bitterness and ill will
example: The acrimonious dispute between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.
translations: n. 辛辣；尖刻；严厉

definition: adjective: refusing to change one's mind
example: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.
translations: adj. 固执的，坚强的；坚定不移的；坚硬无比的
n. 坚硬的东西；坚石

definition: adjective: good enough for what you need
example: A very light jacket will be adequate for Los Angeles's warm winter.
translations: adj. 充足的；适当的；胜任的

definition: verb: to serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion
example: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.
translations: vi. 裁定；宣判
vt. 裁定；宣判

definition: verb: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding
example: Before the concert began, security personel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.
translations: vt. 告诫；劝告

definition: adjective: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective
example: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.
translations: adj. 劝告的，警告的

definition: verb: speak, plead, or argue in favor of
noun: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
example: While the senator privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in a public venue.
Martin Luther King Jr. was a tireless advocate for the rights of African-Americans in the United States.
translations: vt. 提倡，主张，拥护
n. 提倡者；支持者；律师

definition: noun: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
example: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.
translations: n. 唯美主义者；审美家

definition: adjective: concerned with the appreciation of beauty
noun: a set of principles underlying and guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
example: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.
The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph to be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.
translations: adj. 美的；美学的；审美的，具有审美趣味的

definition: adjective: likeable; easy to talk to
example: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn’t around other people.
translations: adj. 和蔼可亲的；友善的

definition: adjective: wealthy
example: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.
translations: adj. 富裕的；丰富的；流畅的
n. 支流；富人

definition: verb: provide with an opportunity
example: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.
translations: vt. 给予，提供；买得起
n. (Afford)人名；(英)阿福德

definition: noun: an eager willingness to do something
example: The first three weeks at his new job, Mark worked with such alacrity that upper management knew it would be giving him a promotion.
translations: n. 敏捷；轻快；乐意

definition: noun: the quality of unselfish concern for the welfare of others
example: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.
translations: n. 利他；利他主义

definition: noun: a mixture of multiple things
example: The band’s music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.
translations: n. [材] 汞合金，[化工] 汞齐；混合物

definition: adjective: open to more than one interpretation
example: The coach told his team, “Move towards that side of the field”; because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.
translations: adj. 模糊不清的；引起歧义的

definition: adjective: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
example: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.
translations: adj. 矛盾的；好恶相克的

definition: verb: make something bad better
example: "Three Cups of Tea" tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.
translations: vt. 改善；减轻（痛苦等）；改良
vi. 变得更好

definition: adjective: easily persuaded
example: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.
translations: adj. 有责任的：顺从的，服从的；有义务的；经得起检验的

definition: adjective: friendly
example: Amy’s name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.
translations: adj. 和蔼可亲的，亲切的
n. (Amiable)人名；(法)阿米亚布勒；(英)阿米娅布尔

definition: adverb: in a frenzied or uncontrolled state
example: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amok, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.
translations: adv. 狂乱地；杀人狂地
adj. 杀人狂的；狂乱的

definition: adjective: shapeless
example: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.
translations: adj. 无定形的；无组织的；[物] 非晶形的

definition: adverb: more than is adequate
example: The boat was amply supplied for its year at sea—no man would go hungry or thirst.
translations: adv. 充足地；广大地
n. (Amply)人名；(俄)安普利

definition: noun: something that is inappropriate for the given time period (usually something old).
example: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.
translations: n. 时代错误；不合潮流的人或物

definition: adjective: similar in some respects but otherwise different
example: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.
translations: adj. 类似的；[昆] 同功的；可比拟的

definition: noun: a detested person; the source of somebody's hate
example: Hundreds of years ago, Galileo was anathema to the church; today the church is anathema to some on the left side of the political spectrum.
translations: n. 诅咒；革出教门；被诅咒者；令人厌恶的人

definition: adjective: lacking energy and vigor
example: After three straight shows, the lead actress gave an anemic performance the fourth night, barely speaking loudly enough for those in the back rows to hear.
translations: adj. 患贫血症的，贫血的

definition: noun: intense hostility
example: The governor’s animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor’s first term.
translations: n. 憎恶，仇恨，敌意

definition: noun: something that soothes or relieves pain
adjective: inoffensive
example: Muzak, which is played in department stores, is intended to be an anodyne, but is often so cheesy and over-the-top that customers become irritated.
Wilbur enjoyed a spicy Mexican breakfast, but Jill preferred a far more anodyne meal in the mornings.
translations: n. [药] 止痛剂；起安慰作用的事物
adj. 止痛的；安慰人的；平淡无奇的

definition: adjective: not normal
example: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous—daily temperatures should return to their old averages, they believe.
translations: adj. 异常的；不规则的；不恰当的

definition: noun: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
example: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.
translations: n. 异常；不规则；反常事物

definition: verb: precede in time
example: Harry was so unknowledgable that he was unaware the Egyptian pharaohs antedated the American Revolution.
translations: vt. 先于；前于
n. 比实际提前的日期

definition: adjective: ludicrously odd
example: The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears.
translations: adj. 古怪的；滑稽可笑的
n. 滑稽动作；丑角
vi. 扮小丑；做滑稽动作
n. (Antic)人名；(法)安蒂克

definition: noun: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
example: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.
translations: n. 反感；厌恶；憎恶；不相容

definition: adjective: old-fashioned; belonging to an earlier period in time
example: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.
translations: adj. 过时的；陈旧的；年老的
v. 使古旧；废弃（antiquate的过去分词）

definition: adjective: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
example: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the disattachment Buddhism preaches.
translations: adj. 对立的，正相反的

definition: adjective: marked by a lack of interest
example: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.
translations: adj. 冷漠的；无动于衷的，缺乏兴趣的

definition: noun: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
example: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.
translations: n. 冷漠，无兴趣，漠不关心；无感情

definition: noun: the highest point
example: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the secondary education system.
translations: n. 顶点；尖端

definition: noun: a short instructive saying about a general truth
example: Nietzsche was known for using aphorisms, sometimes encapsulating a complex philosophical thought in a mere sentence.
translations: n. 格言；警句

definition: adjective: something that is concise and instructive of a general truth or principle
example: Sometimes I can't stand Nathan because he tries to impress everyone by being aphoristic, but he just states the obvious.
translations: adj. 格言（似）的；警句（似）的

definition: noun: great coolness and composure under strain
example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.
translations: n. 沉着；垂直；泰然自若

definition: adjective: being of questionable authenticity
example: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.
translations: adj. 伪的；可疑的

definition: noun: the highest point
example: The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart’s music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.
translations: n. 最高点，极点；远地点
vt. 位于远地点；位于最高点

definition: noun: a person who has abandoned a religious faith or cause
example: An apostate of the Republican Party, Sheldon has yet to become affiliated with any party and dubs himself an independent.
translations: adj. 变节的；脱党的；背教的
n. 脱党者；变节者；叛教者

definition: noun: a short, pithy instructive saying
example: Winston Churchill is famous for many apothegms, but this might be his most famous: "It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all the others that have been tried."
translations: n. 格言；箴言；警句

definition: noun: exaltation to divine status; the highest point of development
example: As difficult as it is to imagine, the apotheosis of Mark Zuckerberg’s career, many believe, is yet to come.
translations: n. 神化；崇拜，颂扬；尊奉为神

definition: verb: pacify by acceding to the demands of
example: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.
translations: vt. 使平息；使满足；使和缓；对…让步

definition: adjective: large enough to be noticed (usu. refers to an amount)
example: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.
translations: adj. 可感知的；可评估的；相当可观的

definition: noun: fearful expectation
example: Test day can be one of pure apprehension, as many students worry about their test scores.
translations: n. 理解；恐惧；逮捕；忧惧

definition: adjective: expressing praise or approval
example: Although it might not be her best work, Hunter's new novel has received generally approbatory reviews.
translations: adj. 认可的；赞赏的

definition: verb: to give or take something by force
verb: to allocate
example: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live.
The committe appropriated the funds to its various members.
translations: adj. 适当的；恰当的；合适的
vt. 占用，拨出

definition: adjective: supply added support
example: n hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.
translations: adj. 从属的；附属的
n. 附属物（等于appurtenance）

definition: adjective: based on a random, groundless decision
example: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.
translations: adj. [数] 任意的；武断的；专制的

definition: adjective: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
example: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to the join the fraterntiy must learn.
translations: adj. 神秘的；晦涩难解的；秘传的

definition: adjective: to be deliberately teasing
example: The baroness was arch, making playful asides to the townspeople; yet because they couldn't pick up on her dry humor, they thought her supercilious.
translations: n. 弓形，拱形；拱门
adj. 主要的
vt. 使…弯成弓形；用拱连接
vi. 拱起；成为弓形
n. (Arch)人名；(德)阿尔希；(英)阿奇

definition: adjective: so old as to appear to belong to a different period
example: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice--needless to say, she didn't have many friends.
translations: adj. 古代的；陈旧的；古体的；古色古香的

definition: adjective: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
example: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.
translations: adj. 努力的；费力的；险峻的

definition: adjective: complete and wholly (usually modifying a noun with negative connotation)
example: An arrant fool, Lawrence surprised nobody when he lost all his money in a pyramid scheme that was every bit as transparent as it was corrupt.
translations: adj. 极恶的；声名狼藉的；彻头彻尾的

definition: noun: a person who has recently reached a position of power; a social climber
example: The city center was aflutter with arrivistes who each tried to outdo one another with their ostentatious sports cars and chic evening dress.
translations: n. 暴发户；一心想发迹的人；野心家

definition: verb: seize and control without authority
example: Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink, and entertainment.
translations: vt. 冒称；霸占；没来由地将…归属于

definition: adjective: exhibiting artistic skill;
adjective: clever in a cunning way
example: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.;
Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.
translations: adj. 巧妙的；狡猾的；有技巧的；欺诈的

definition: noun: cunning tricks used to deceive others
example: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.
translations: n. 诡计；欺骗；巧妙的办法
n. (Artifice)人名；(葡)阿蒂菲塞

definition: adjective: without cunning or deceit
example: Despite the president's seemingly artless speeches, he was a skilled and ruthless negotiator.
translations: adj. 天真的；朴实的；无虚饰的

definition: noun: the quality of innocence
example: I, personally, found the artlessness of her speech charming.
translations: n. 天真烂漫；淳朴；笨拙

definition: noun: the state that exists when one person or group has power over another
example: The ascendancy of the Carlsbad water polo team is clear—they have a decade of championships behind them.
translations: n. 优势；支配地位（等于ascendency，ascendence）

definition: adjective: practicing self-denial
noun: one who practices great self-denial
example: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired so many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.
Historically, ascetics like Ghandi are often considered wise men partially because of their restraint.
translations: adj. 苦行的；禁欲主义的
n. 苦行者；禁欲者

definition: verb: attribute or credit to
example: History ascribes The Odyssey and The Iliad to Homer, but scholars now debate whether he was a historical figure or a fictitious name.
translations: vt. 归因于；归咎于

definition: adverb: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
example: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"
translations: adv. 怀疑地；斜视地

definition: noun: harshness of manner
example: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.
translations: n. （表面的）粗糙；（气候等的）严酷；艰苦的条件；（性格）粗暴

definition: verb: attack in speech or writing
example: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.
translations: vt. 攻击；质问；着手解决

definition: adverb: with care and persistence
example: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.
translations: adv. 刻苦地；勤勉地

definition: verb: make something intense less severe
example: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in line.
translations: vt. 平息；缓和；减轻

definition: noun: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic; throwback
example: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.
translations: n. 返祖现象；隔代遗传

definition: verb: to weaken (in terms of intensity); to taper off/become thinner.
example: Her animosity towards Bob attenuated over the years, and she even went so far as to invite him to her party.
translations: adj. 减弱的；稀薄的；细小的
vt. 使减弱；使纤细
vi. 变纤细；变弱

definition: adjective: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
example: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.
translations: adj. 无畏的；鲁莽的

definition: noun: aggressive boldness in social situations
example: She surprised her colleagues by having the audacity to publically criticize the findings of an distinguished scientist.
translations: n. 大胆；厚颜无耻

definition: verb: enlarge or increase; improve
example: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.
translations: vi. 增加；增大
vt. 增加；增大
n. 增加；增大

definition: adjective: favorable, the opposite of sinister
example: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike’s road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.
translations: adj. 吉兆的，吉利的；幸运的

definition: adjective: practicing self-denial
adjective: unadorned in style or appearance
adjective: harsh in manner of temperament
example: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.
Late Soviet architecture, although remaining largely austere, moved into experimental territory that employed previously unused shapes and structures.
The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.
translations: adj. 严峻的；简朴的；苦行的；无装饰的

definition: adjective: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule; having absolute sovereignty
adjective: offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power
example: The last true autocratic country is certainly North Korea; nowhere does a leader exercise the absolute control over all aspects of a people the way that Kim Jong-un does.
The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.
translations: adj. 专制的；独裁的，专横的

definition: adverb: In an autonomous or self-governing manner.
example: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.
translations: adv. 自治地；独立自主地

definition: noun: greed (one of the seven deadly sins)
example: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.
translations: n. 贪婪，贪财

definition: adjective: excessively greedy
example: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust--sins of excess--it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.
translations: adj. 贪婪的；贪得无厌的

definition: verb: turn away
verb: ward off or prevent
example: Afraid to see the aftermath of the car crash, I averted my eyes as we drove by.
The struggling videogame company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankruptcy.
translations: vt. 避免，防止；转移

definition: adjective: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
example: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.
translations: adj. 渴望的，贪婪的；热心的
n. (Avid)人名；(俄)阿维德

definition: verb: to pester
example: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.
translations: n. 獾；獾皮；（大写）獾州人（美国威斯康星州人的别称）；<动><澳>毛鼻袋熊
vt. 纠缠不休；吵着要；烦扰
n. (Badger)人名；(英)巴杰

definition: adjective: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
example: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.
translations: adj. 恶意的；有害的

definition: verb: refuse to comply
example: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.
translations: n. 障碍；错误

translations: adj. 相称的；同量的；同样大小的

definition: adjective: contented to a fault with oneself or one's actions
example: After the water polo team won their sixth championship, they became complacent and didn't even make it to the playoffs the next year.
translations: adj. 自满的；得意的；满足的

definition: adjective: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
example: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employee and anticipating future requests.
translations: adj. 彬彬有礼的；顺从的；殷勤的

definition: adjective: enhancing each other's qualities (for two things or more).
example: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.
translations: adj. 补足的，补充的

definition: adjective: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable nature.
example: While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.
translations: adj. 有同谋关系的，串通一气的

definition: verb: make more intense, stronger, or more marked
example: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.
translations: n. [化学] 化合物；混合物；复合词
adj. 复合的；混合的
v. 合成；混合；恶化，加重；和解，妥协

definition: verb: acknowledge defeat
verb: admit (to a wrongdoing)
verb: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another
example: I concede. You win!
After a long, stern lecture from her father, Olivia conceded to having broken the window.
The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory they had previously conquered.
translations: vt. 承认；退让；给予，容许
vi. 让步

definition: verb: to make peace with
example: His opponents believed his gesture to be conciliatory, yet as soon as they put down their weapons, he unsheathed a hidden sword.
translations: vt. 安抚，安慰；调和；驯服；怀柔；赢得

definition: adjective: describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in connection with another
example: Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.
translations: adj. 相伴的；共存的；附随的
n. 伴随物

definition: adjective: making a situation or outcome more likely to happen
example: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.
translations: adj. 有益的；有助于…的

definition: noun: a very intense and uncontrolled fire
example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, do to the heat and lack of rain.
translations: n. 大火；快速燃烧；突发；冲突

definition: verb: mix together different elements or concepts
example: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.
translations: vt. 合并；异文合并

definition: verb: be confusing or perplexing to
verb: mistake one thing for another
example: Though Harry loved numbers, he found calculus confounding.
Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.
translations: vt. 使混淆；挫败；讨厌；使混乱

definition: verb: taking part in immoral and unethical plots
example: The queen was so conniving that, with the help of the prince, she tried to overthrow the king.
translations: adj. 纵容的；默许的
v. 纵容；默许；假装不见；共谋（connive的ing形式）

definition: verb: taking part in immoral and unethical plots
example: The queen was so conniving that, with the help of the prince, she tried to overthrow the king.
translations: adj. 纵容的；默许的
v. 纵容；默许；假装不见；共谋（connive的ing形式）

definition: verb: to make holy or set apart for a high purpose
example: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.
translations: vt. 奉献；使神圣；供神用；献身于
adj. 神圣的；被献给神的

definition: adjective: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
example: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad--not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.
translations: adj. 显著的；显而易见的

definition: noun: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes
noun: an abstract part of something
example: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.
The constituents of the metal alloy are nickel, copper, and tin.
translations: n. 成分；选民；委托人
adj. 构成的；选举的

definition: noun: something that limits or restricts
example: We don't have many resources, so we'll have to work with some very tight constraints.
translations: n. [数] 约束；局促，态度不自然；强制

definition: verb: interpreted in a particular way
example: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.
translations: vt. 分析；解释；翻译
vi. 作文法性的分析

definition: adjective: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill
verb: to make perfect and complete in every respect
example: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.
The restoration of the ancient church was only consummated after a twenty years of labor.
translations: adj. 至上的；完美的；圆满的
vt. 完成；作成；使达到极点

definition: adjective: scornful, looking down at others with a sneering attitude
example: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.
translations: adj. 轻蔑的；侮辱的

definition: adjective: likely to argue
example: Since old grandpa Harry became very contentious during the summer when only reruns were on T.V., the grandkids learned to hide from him at every opportunity.
translations: adj. 诉讼的；有异议的，引起争论的；爱争论的

definition: noun: a gathering of persons representative of some larger group
adjective: possible but not certain to occur
example: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.
Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.
translations: adj. 因情况而异的；不一定的；偶然发生的；可能的；依情况而定的；偶然的；[逻]有条件的
n. 分遣队；偶然事件；分得部分；代表团

definition: adjective: to be remorseful
example: Though he stole his little sister’s licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.
translations: adj. 悔悟了的；后悔的；悔罪的

definition: noun: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
example: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.
translations: n. 痛悔；悔悟

definition: verb: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
example: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.
translations: vt. 设计；发明；图谋
vi. 谋划；设法做到

definition: noun: a difficult problem
example: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.
translations: n. 难题；谜语

definition: adjective: describing a lively atmosphere
example: The wedding reception was convivial; friends who hadn't seen each other for ages drank and ate together before heading to the dance floor.
translations: adj. 欢乐的；欢宴的；酒宴的

definition: adjective: highly complex or intricate
example: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.
translations: adj. 复杂的；费解的；旋绕的
v. 盘绕；缠绕（convolute的过去分词）

definition: adjective: in abundant supply
example: In midsummer, there are copious popiscle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.
translations: adj. 丰富的；很多的；多产的

definition: noun: an abundant supply of something good
example: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.
translations: n. 哺乳宙斯的羊角；装满花果及谷穗表丰饶的羊角状物；丰饶的象征

definition: noun: a practical consequence that follows naturally
example: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.
translations: n. 推论；必然的结果

definition: verb: to confirm or lend support to (usually an idea or claim)
example: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.
translations: vt. 证实；使坚固

definition: adjective: comprising many cultures; global in reach and outlook
example: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.
translations: adj. 世界性的；世界主义的，四海一家的
n. 四海为家者；世界主义者；世界各地都有的东西

definition: verb: treat with excessive indulgence
example: The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.
translations: vt. 宠爱；溺爱；纵容
n. 宠儿；爱畜；供玩赏的小动物
n. (Cosset)人名；(法)科塞

definition: adjective: being of equal extent or scope or duration
example: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.
translations: adj. 相连的；毗连的（等于conterminous）

definition: verb: a contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command
example: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.
translations: n. 取消；反对命令
vt. 取消，撤消；下反对命令召回

definition: verb: to intimidate
example: Do not be cowed by a 3,000-word vocabulary list: turn that list into a deck of flashcards!
translations: n. 奶牛，母牛；母兽
vt. 威胁，恐吓

definition: adjective: pathetically cowardly
example: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.
translations: adj. 畏缩的；怯懦的
n. 懦夫
n. (Craven)人名；(意)克拉文；(英)克雷文

definition: noun: belief in something
example: He placed no credence in psychics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.
translations: n. 信任；凭证；祭器台（等于credence table，credenza）

definition: adjective: deserving of praise but not that amazing
example: Critics agreed the movie was creditable, but few gave it more than three out of five stars.
translations: adj. 声誉好的；值得称赞的；应当认可的

definition: noun: tendency to believe readily
example: Virginia's wide-eyed credulity as a five-year old was replaced by suspicion after she learned that Santa Claus didn't really exist.
translations: n. 轻信；易受骗

definition: adjective: brought low in spirit
example: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.
translations: adj. 垂头丧气的，气馁的

definition: adjective: mysterious or vague, usually intentionally
example: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.
translations: adj. 神秘的，含义模糊的；[动] 隐藏的

definition: verb: cause to take on a definite and clear shape
example: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.
translations: vt. 使结晶；明确；使具体化；做成蜜饯
vi. 结晶，形成结晶；明确；具体化

definition: verb: reach the highest or most decisive point
example: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.
translations: vi. 到绝顶；达到高潮；达到顶点
vt. 使结束；使达到高潮

definition: noun: a state of guilt
example: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.
translations: n. 可责；有过失；有罪

definition: adjective: difficult to handle or use especially because of size or weight
example: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books--these days we need only an e-reader.
translations: adj. 笨重的；累赘的；难处理的

definition: noun: greed for money
example: Some believe people that amassing as much wealth as possible is the meaning to life—yet they often realize that cupidity brings anything but happiness.
translations: n. 贪心，贪婪

definition: noun: a grouchy, surly person
example: Since Uncle Mike was the family curmudgeon, each Thanksgiving he was plied with copious amounts of wine, in the hope that he would become less grouchy.
translations: n. 脾气坏的人，乖戾的人；吝啬鬼；存心不良的人

definition: noun: a lack or shortage
example: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.
translations: n. 缺乏；饥馑；粮食不足
n. (Dearth)人名；(英)迪尔思

definition: verb: reduce the quality or value of something
example: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.
translations: vt. 降低；使…贬值；掺杂
n. (Debase)人名；(意)德巴塞

definition: adjective: having a sophisticated charm
example: James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets, and debonair manner.
translations: adj. 高兴的，快活的；温文尔雅的；殷勤的

definition: verb: expose as false ideas and claims, especially while ridiculing
example: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.
translations: vt. 揭穿；拆穿…的假面具；暴露

definition: noun: destroying or killing a large part of the population
example: The decimation after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki is incomprehensible.
translations: n. 大批杀害；每十人杀一人；大量毁灭

definition: adjective: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
example: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.
translations: adj. 有礼貌的，高雅的；端正的

definition: noun: propriety in manners and conduct
example: "You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell," said the judge to the prosecutor.
translations: n. 礼仪；礼貌；端正；恪守礼仪

definition: verb: express strong disapproval of
example: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.
translations: vt. 责难，谴责；诽谤

definition: adjective: showing respect
example: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.
translations: adj. 恭敬的；惯于顺从的

definition: verb: to help pay the cost of, either in part of full
example: In order for Sean to attend the prestigious college, his generous uncle helped defray the excessive tuition with a monthly donation.
translations: vt. 支出；支付

definition: verb: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally
example: Jesse had mockingly pointed out all of Nancy's faults in front of their friends, publicly degrading the poor girl.
translations: vt. 贬低；使……丢脸；使……降级；使……降解
vi. 降级，降低；退化

definition: verb: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity
example: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.
translations: vi. 屈尊
vt. 赐予

definition: verb: give an assignment to (a person)
example: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.
translations: vt. 委派…为代表
n. 代表

definition: adjective: harmful to living things
example: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.
translations: adj. 有毒的，有害的

definition: verb: think about carefully; weigh the pros and cons of an issue
example: Emergency situations such as this call for immediate action and leave no room to deliberate over options.
translations: adj. 故意的；深思熟虑的；从容的
vt. 仔细考虑；商议

definition: verb: describe in detail
example: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stroke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.
translations: vt. 描绘；描写；画…的轮廓

definition: verb: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect
example: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.
translations: vt. 贬低...的身份；使...失去尊严

definition: adjective: given to or marked by the open expression of emotion
example: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.
translations: adj. 说明的；证明的；公开表露感情的
n. 指示词

definition: verb: to object or show reluctance
example: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they going skiing in the Alps.
translations: vi. 反对；抗辩；提出异议
n. 异议；反对
n. (Demur)人名；(德)德穆尔；(法)德米尔

definition: adjective: to be modest and shy
example: The portrait of her in a simple white blouse was sweet and demure.
translations: adj. 端庄的；娴静的；严肃的；假装正直的
n. (Demure)人名；(法)德米尔

definition: verb: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone
example: Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.
translations: vt. 诋毁；使变黑；玷污

definition: verb: be a sign or indication of; have as a meaning
example: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes "stop" to all motorists in America.
translations: vt. 表示，指示

definition: noun: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the outcome of a complex sequence of events
example: At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.
translations: n. 结局；终场

definition: adjective: (of a person) not doing one's duties
noun: (of a building) abandoned
example: The teacher was derelict in her duties because she hadn't graded a single student paper in three weeks.
At one time the waterfront factories were busy and productive, but now they stand derelict and will be torn down.
translations: adj. 玩忽职守的；无主的；被抛弃了的
n. 遗弃物；玩忽职守者；被遗弃的人

definition: verb: treat or speak of with contempt
example: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.
translations: vt. 嘲笑；嘲弄

definition: adjective: abusing vocally; expressing contempt or ridicule
example: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.
translations: adj. 嘲笑的，嘲弄的；可付之一笑的

definition: adjective: (or a creative product, e.g. music, writing, etc.) not original but drawing on the work of another person
example: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.
translations: n. [化学] 衍生物，派生物；导数
adj. 派生的；引出的

definition: verb: come from; be connected by a relationship of blood, for example
verb: reason by deduction; establish by deduction
example: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word "derive."
From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue: Sheila was not alone in the room at the time of the murder.
translations: vt. 源于；得自；获得
vi. 起源
n. (Derive)人名；(法)德里夫

definition: adjective: expressed as worthless or in negative terms
example: Never before have we seen a debate between two political candidates that was so derogative and filthy.
translations: adj. 减损的；毁损的

definition: verb: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place
example: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.
translations: vt. 亵渎；污辱；把（神物）供俗用

definition: adjective: uninteresting, lacking vitality
example: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books.
translations: adj. 干的（等于desiccate）；粉状的
v. 使干燥（desiccate的过去式）；变干

definition: noun: something desired as a necessity
example: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.
translations: n. 迫切需要之物；所愿望之物

definition: preposition: even with (when an event is surprising because of some difficulty)
example: We enjoyed our vacation despite the rain.
translations: prep. 尽管，不管
n. 轻视；憎恨；侮辱

definition: noun: a cruel and oppressive dictator
example: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.
translations: n. 专制君主，暴君；独裁者
n. (Despot)人名；(塞、罗)德斯波特

definition: adjective: poor enough to need help from others
adjective: completely wanting or lacking (usually "destitute of")
example: Jean Valjean, is at first destitute, but through the grace of a priest, he makes something of his life.
Now that the mine is closed, the town is destitute of any economic activity.
translations: adj. 穷困的；无的；缺乏的
n. 赤贫者
vt. 使穷困；夺去

definition: verb: turn away from by persuasion
verb: try to prevent; show opposition to
example: His mother tried to deter him from joining the army, but he was too intoxicated with the idea of war to listen.
The government's primary job should involve deterring paths to war, not finding ways to start them.
translations: vt. 制止，阻止；使打消念头
n. (Deter)人名；(德)德特尔

definition: adjective: (sometimes followed by "to") causing harm or injury
example: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.
translations: adj. 不利的；有害的
n. 有害的人（或物）；不受欢迎的求婚者

definition: verb: pass on or delegate to another
verb: grow worse (usually "devolve into")
example: The company was full of managers known for devolving tasks to lower management, but never doing much work themselves.
The dialogue between the two academics devolved into a downright bitter argument.
translations: vi. 被移交；转让
vt. 转移；移交；使滚下；衰落

definition: adjective: to be extremely wicked like the devil
example: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.
translations: adj. 恶魔的

definition: noun: a strong verbal attack against a person or institution
example: Steve’s mom launched into a diatribe during the PTA meeting, contending that the school was little more than a daycare in which students stare at the wall and teachers stare at the chalkboard.
translations: n. 诽谤；恶骂

definition: adjective: expecting unquestioning obedience; characteristic of an absolute ruler
example: The coach was dictatorial in his approach: no players could ever argue or question his approach.
translations: adj. 独裁的，专政的；专横傲慢的

definition: adjective: instructive (especially excessively)
example: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Illyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.
translations: adj. 说教的；教诲的

definition: verb: be a distinctive feature, attribute, or trait (sometimes in positive sense)
verb: evolve so as to lead to a new species or develop in a way most suited to the environment
example: Mozart's long melodic lines differentiate his compositions from other works of late 18th century music.
Animals on Madagascar differentiated from other similar animal species due to many years of isolation on the island.
translations: vi. 区分，区别
vt. 区分，区别

definition: adjective: showing modest reserve; lacking self-confidence
example: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.
translations: adj. 羞怯的；缺乏自信的；谦虚谨慎的

definition: adjective: in terrible condition
example: The main house has been restored but the gazebo is still dilapidated and unuseable.
translations: adj. 荒废的，要塌似的；破坏的
v. 变得荒废（dilapidate的过去分词）

definition: adjective: wasting time
example: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.
translations: adj. 拖拉的；缓慢的，不慌不忙的

definition: noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
example: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante
translations: n. 业余爱好者；一知半解者
adj. 浅薄的；业余艺术爱好的
vi. （在艺术、科学等方面）浅尝辄止

definition: adjective: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks
example: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.
translations: adj. 勤勉的；用功的，费尽心血的
n. (Diligent)人名；(法)迪利让

definition: noun: to indicate smallness
adjective: very small
example: He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: "Bill" instead of "John William."
When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.
translations: adj. 小的，小型的，微小的
n. 爱称；指小词；身材极小的人

definition: verb: to persuade somebody that his/her belief is not valid
example: As a child, I was quickly disabused of the notion that Santa Claus was a rotund benefactor of infinite largess—one night I saw my mother diligently wrapping presents and storing them under our Christmas tree.
translations: vt. 使省悟；解迷惑；释疑；矫正

definition: adjective: discontented as toward authority
example: After watching his superior take rations from the soliders, he quickly became disaffected and rebeled.
translations: adj. 不满的；有叛意的；愤愤不平的
v. 使疏远；使不友爱（disaffect的过去分词）

definition: noun: lack of agreement or harmony
example: Despite all their talented players, the team was filled with discord--some players refused to talk to others--and lost most of their games.
translations: n. 不和；不调和；嘈杂声
vi. 不一致；刺耳
n. (Discord)人名；(法)迪斯科尔

definition: adjective: careful to protect one's speech or actions in order to avoid offense or gain an advantage
example: The professor thought that he was discreet, subtly wiping the stain off of his shirt, but as soon as he stepped off the podium a member of the audience pointed out the large ketchup stain.
translations: adj. 谨慎的；小心的

definition: adjective: constituting a separate entity or part
example: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.
translations: adj. 离散的，不连续的
n. 分立元件；独立部件

definition: verb: recognize or perceive the difference
example: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.
translations: vt. 歧视；区别；辨别
vi. 区别；辨别

definition: adjective: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point
example: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.
translations: adj. 散漫的；离题的；东拉西扯的；无层次的

definition: verb: deprive of voting rights
example: The U.S. Constitution disenfranchised women until 1920 when they were given the right to vote.
translations: vt. 剥夺…的公民权（等于disfranchise）

definition: adjective: made less hopeful or enthusiastic
example: After the visiting team scored nine times, the home team's fans were disheartened, some leaving the game early.
translations: adj. 沮丧的；灰心的
v. 使沮丧；使泄气；使失去勇气（dishearten的过去式和过去分词）

definition: adjective: not straightforward; giving a false appearance of frankness
example: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.
translations: adj. 虚伪的；不诚实的；不老实的；狡猾的

definition: adjective: unbiased; neutral
example: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.
translations: adj. 无私的；公正的；冷漠的；廉洁的
v. 使不再有利害关系；使无兴趣（disinterest的过去分词）

definition: adjective: two things are fundamentally different
example: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.
translations: adj. 不同的；不相干的；全异的
n. 无法相比的东西

definition: adjective: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
example: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.
translations: adj. 不带感情的；平心静气的；公平的

definition: noun: the property of being prompt and efficient
verb: dispose of rapidly and without delay and efficiently
example: She finished her thesis with dispatch, amazing her advisors who couldn't believe she hadn't written 60 scholarly pages so quickly.
As soon as the angry peasants stormed the castle, they caught the king and swiftly dispatched him.
translations: n. 派遣；急件
vt. 派遣；分派

definition: noun: an exemption from a rule or obligation
example: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.
translations: n. 分配；免除；豁免；天命

definition: verb: conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit
example: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.
translations: vt. 掩饰，掩盖；假装
vi. 隐藏，掩饰（思想、感情等）

definition: verb: cause to become widely known
example: Before the effects of anaethesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.
translations: vt. 宣传，传播；散布
vi. 散布；广为传播

definition: verb: squander or spend money frivolously
verb: to disperse or scatter
example: The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico.
Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.
translations: vt. 浪费；使…消散
vi. 驱散；放荡

definition: noun: a living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure
example: Many Roman emperors were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.
translations: n. 分解，溶解；（议会等的）解散；（契约等的）解除；死亡

definition: adjective: easily handled or managed; willing to be taught or led or supervised or directed
example: Barnyard animals are considerably more docile than the wild animals.
translations: adj. 温顺的，驯服的；容易教的

definition: verb: to pursue relentlessly; to hound
example: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.
translations: n. 狗；丑女人；卑鄙的人；(俚)朋友
vt. 跟踪；尾随

definition: adjective: highly opinionated, not accepting that your belief may not be correct
example: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.
translations: adj. 教条的；武断的

definition: adjective: filled with or evoking sadness
example: No event is more doleful than the passing of my mother; she was a shining star in my life, and it brings me great sadness to think that she is now gone.
translations: adj. 寂寞的；悲哀的；阴沉的；忧郁的

definition: adjective: showing sorrow
example: Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.
translations: adj. 忧伤的；悲痛的

definition: adjective: brave; bold; courageous
example: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.
translations: adj. 勇敢强悍的；坚强的；勇猛的
n. (Doughty)人名；(英)道蒂

definition: verb: fit together tightly, as if by means of a interlocking joint
example: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail very well.
translations: vt. 用鸠尾榫接合；与…吻合
vi. 吻合
n. 楔形榫头

definition: verb: to trick or swindle
noun: a person who is easily tricked or swindled
example: Once again a get-rich-fast Internet scheme had duped Harold into submitting a $5,000 check to a sham operation.
The charlatan mistook the crowd for a bunch of dupes, but the crowd was quickly on to him and decried his bald-faced attempt to bilk them.
translations: n. 上当者；易受骗的人
vt. 欺骗；愚弄（等于duplicate）

definition: noun: deceitfulness, pretending to want one thing but interested in something else
example: A life of espionage is one of duplicity: an agent must pretend to be a totally different person than who she or he actually is.
translations: n. 口是心非；表里不一；不诚实

definition: noun: compulsory force or threat
example: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.
translations: n. 强迫；监禁

definition: adjective: joyously unrestrained
example: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.
translations: adj. 热情洋溢的；沸腾的

definition: adjective: highly unconventional or unusual (usually describes a person)
example: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.
translations: adj. 古怪的，反常的
n. 古怪的人

definition: adjective: comprised of a variety of styles
example: Joey was known for his eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next "air conducting" along to Beethoven's 9th symphony.
translations: adj. 折衷的；选择的；折衷学派的
n. 折衷派的人；折衷主义者
adj. 不拘一格的

definition: adjective: avoiding waste, efficient
example: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.
translations: adj. 经济的；节约的；合算的

definition: adjective: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
example: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.
translations: adj. 有益的；有教化意味的
v. 熏陶（edify的ing形式）；启迪

definition: adjective: marked by high spirits or excitement
example: After the sales result, the manager was in an effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work early that day.
translations: adj. 冒泡的，沸腾的；兴奋的

definition: adjective: producing the intended result
example: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.
translations: adj. 有效的；灵验的

definition: noun: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to
example: The skateboarders acted with effrontery, skating through the church grounds and spray-painting signs warning trespassers.
translations: n. 厚颜无耻

definition: noun: a conceited and self-centered person
example: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.
translations: n. 自高自大者；言必称“我”者（形容词egotistic，副词egotistically）

definition: adjective: standing out in negative way; shockingly bad
example: The dictator’s abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.
translations: adj. 惊人的；过分的；恶名昭彰的

definition: verb: To live off meager resources, to scrape by
example: Stranded in a cabin over the winter, Terry was able to eke out an existence on canned food.
translations: vt. 竭力增补；勉强维持；竭力维持

definition: adjective: marked by complexity and richness of detail
verb: explain in more detail
example: Thomas, on returning from Morocco, replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.
Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.
translations: adj. 精心制作的；详尽的；煞费苦心的
vt. 精心制作；详细阐述；从简单成分合成（复杂有机物）
vi. 详细描述；变复杂

definition: adjective: expressing sorrow
example: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.
translations: adj. 挽歌的；哀悼的，哀伤的
n. 挽歌，哀歌

definition: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.
translations: vt. 抽出，引出；引起

definition: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
example: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.
translations: vt. 抽出，引出；引起

definition: verb: make clearer and easier to understand
example: Youtube is great place to learn just about anything--an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.
translations: vt. 阐明；说明

definition: verb: escape understanding
example: Even a basic understanding of physics can elude most high schools students.
translations: vt. （尤指机智地，巧妙地）避开，逃避，躲避
vt. 使无法得到；使无法达到
vt. 使不记得；使不理解

definition: adjective: difficult to capture or difficult to remember
example: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.
translations: adj. 难懂的；易忘的；逃避的；难捉摸的

definition: verb: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.; make more beautiful
example: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.
translations: vt. 修饰；装饰；润色
vi. 装饰起来；加以润色

definition: adjective: involved in argument or contention
example: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal—a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.
translations: adj. 卷入的；纠缠不清的
v. 卷入（embroil的过去式和过去分词）；牵连

definition: adjective: standing above others in quality or position
example: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.
translations: adj. 杰出的；有名的；明显的

definition: adjective: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and emotions
example: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspirations and fears.
translations: adj. 移情作用的；同感的（等于empathic）

definition: noun: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science as a way to gain insight and knowledge
example: Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.
translations: n. 经验主义；经验论

definition: verb: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating; compete with successfully
example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.
translations: vt. 仿真；模仿；尽力赶上；同…竞争
n. 仿真；仿效

definition: verb: attraction or feeling of love
example: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.
translations: vt. 使迷恋，使倾心

definition: verb: hold back
example: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.
translations: vt. 阻塞；妨害；拖累

definition: adjective: native; originating where it is found
example: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.
translations: adj. 地方性的；风土的
n. 地方病

definition: verb: to sap energy from

translations: vt. 使衰弱，使失去活力
adj. 衰弱的，无力的

definition: verb: give rise to
example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.
translations: vt. 使产生；造成
vi. 产生；引起

definition: verb: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority
example: The government agency enjoined the chemical company to clean up the hazardous dump it had created over the years.
translations: vt. 命令；吩咐；嘱咐；禁止

definition: noun: a state of deep-seated ill-will
example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.
translations: n. 敌意；憎恨

definition: noun: an act of extreme wickedness
example: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words--within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.
translations: n. 巨大；暴行；极恶

definition: verb: hold spellbound
example: She was so enthralled by the movie that she never heard people screaming, "Fire! Fire!" in the neighboring theater.
translations: vt. 迷住，使着迷

definition: verb: get someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises
example: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.
translations: vt. 诱使；怂恿

definition: adjective: fixed firmly or securely
example: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.
translations: adj. 根深蒂固的；确立的，不容易改的
v. 确立；保证；挖掘壕沟（entrench的过去分词）

definition: verb: determine the number or amount of
verb: specify individually, one by one
example: The survey enumerates the number of happy workers and the number of unhappy workers.
I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.
translations: vt. 列举；枚举；计算

definition: adjective: lasting a very short time
example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.
translations: adj. 短暂的；朝生暮死的
n. 只生存一天的事物

definition: noun: a witty saying
example: My favorite epigram from Mark Twain is "A man who carries a cat by the tail learns something he can learn no other way."
translations: n. 警句；讽刺短诗；隽语

definition: noun: a sudden revelation or moment of insight
example: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he prompty quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.
translations: 对事物真谛的顿悟；主显节（每年一月六日纪念耶稣显灵的节日）；显现（特指神的显现）

definition: noun: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is named
example: Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.
translations: n. 名字被用于命名地方的人，齐名的人

definition: adjective: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience
example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting—at least until the ice cream is gone.
translations: adj. 公平的，公正的；平衡法的

definition: adjective: confusing or ambiguous
example: The findings of the study were equivocal—the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.
translations: adj. 模棱两可的；可疑的

definition: verb: to speak vaguely, usually with the intention to mislead or deceive
example: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.
translations: vi. 说模棱两可的话；支吾， 躲闪；推诿；含糊其词

definition: verb: to completely destroy
example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.
translations: vt. 根除，根绝；消灭

definition: verb: to make an error
example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.
translations: vi. 犯错；做错；犯罪；走上歧途

definition: adjective: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path
example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.
translations: adj. 不定的；周游的；错误的；偏离正路的

definition: adjective: unpredictable; strange and unconventional
example: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President’s attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.
translations: adj. 不稳定的；古怪的
n. 漂泊无定的人；古怪的人

definition: adjective: not real or genuine; phony
example: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelley found highly inflated.
translations: adj. 代用的；人造的；假的
n. 代用品；仿制品

definition: adjective: having or showing profound knowledge
example: Before the Internet, the library was typically were you would find erudite readers.
translations: adj. 博学的；有学问的
n. 饱学之士

definition: verb: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
example: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.
translations: vt. 避免；避开；远避

definition: adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pasttime.
translations: adj. 秘传的；限于圈内人的；难懂的

definition: verb: to adopt or support an idea or cause
example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.
translations: vt. 支持；嫁娶；赞成；信奉

definition: adjective: deserving of esteem and respect
example: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.
translations: adj. 可估计的；可尊敬的；有价值的

definition: adjective: characterized by lightness and insubstantiality
example: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.
translations: adj. 优雅的；轻飘的；缥缈的；超凡的

definition: noun: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
example: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.
translations: n. 精神欢快，[临床] 欣快；兴高采烈；欣快症；幸福愉快感

definition: adjective: tending to vanish like vapor
example: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time—an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.
translations: adj. 容易消散的；逐渐消失的；会凋零的

definition: adjective: avoiding or escaping from difficulty or danger or commitment
adjective: deliberately vague or ambiguous
example: His responses were clearly evasive; he obviously did not want to take on any responsibility or any new work.
Every time I call the bank, I receive the same evasive answers about our mortgage and never get a clear response.
translations: adj. 逃避的；托辞的；推托的

definition: adjective: without partiality
example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.
translations: adj. 公平的；公平无私的

definition: verb: make worse
example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.
translations: vt. 使加剧；使恶化；激怒

definition: adjective: requiring and demanding accuracy

translations: adj. 严格的；苛求的；吃力的
v. 逼取；急需（exact的ing形式）

definition: verb: praise or glorify
example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.
translations: vt. 提升；提拔；赞扬；使得意
vi. 使人得意

definition: verb: to irritate intensely
example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.
translations: vt. 恶化；使恼怒；激怒

definition: verb: to criticize very harshly
example: Entrusted with the prototype to his company’s latest smartphone, Larry, during a late night karaoke bout, let the prototype slip into the hands of a rival company—the next day Larry was excoriated, and then fired.
translations: vt. 严厉的责难；擦破...的皮肤

definition: adjective: extremely painful
example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.
translations: adj. 折磨人的；使苦恼的
v. 折磨；使苦恼；使受酷刑（excruciate的ing形式）

definition: verb: to curse and hiss at
example: Though the new sitcom did decently in the ratings, Nelson railed against the show, saying that it was nothing more than an execrable pastiche of tired cliché’s and canned laughter.
translations: vt. 诅咒；憎恶；痛骂
vi. 诅咒

definition: noun: critical explanation or analysis, especially of a text
example: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis—over the past five centuries there have been as many interpretations as there are pages in the Old Testament.
translations: n. 注释，解释

definition: noun: something to be imitated
example: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat, and thoughtful work.
translations: n. 模范，榜样；标本

definition: verb: be characteristic of
verb: clarify by giving an example of

translations: vt. 例证；例示

definition: verb: to strongly urge on; encourage
example: Nelson’s parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.
translations: vt. 忠告；劝诫
vi. 劝告

definition: noun: the quality of being meager
example: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.
translations: n. 微小；些许，稀少

translations: n. 富裕；丰富

adjective: miserly

；Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.
