translations: n. 骚动；骚乱；吵闹；激动

definition: adjective: (of language) pompous and tedious
example: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years--by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his diehard fans refused to read them.
translations: adj. 肿胀的；浮夸的；浮肿的

definition: noun: depravity; a depraved act
example: During his reign, Caligula indulged in unspeakable sexual practices, so it not surprising that he will forever be remembered for his turpitude.
translations: n. 卑鄙；奸恶

definition: noun: someone new to a field or activity
example: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time—unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.
translations: n. 新手，生手；初学者

definition: noun: a feeling of anger caused by being offended
example: Since he was so in love with her, he took umbrage at her comments, even though she had only meant to gently tease him.
translations: n. 不快，生气；树荫；怀疑

definition: adjective: immune to attack; without flaws
example: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.
translations: adj. 不容置疑的；无懈可击的

definition: adjective: suggesting the operation of supernatural influences; surpassing the ordinary or normal
example: Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.
translations: adj. 神秘的；离奇的；可怕的

definition: adjective: not making concessions
example: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.
translations: adj. 不妥协的，不让步的；坚定的

definition: adjective: unreasonable; unscrupulous; excessive
example: The lawyer’s demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.
translations: adj. 不合理的；昧着良心的；肆无忌惮的；过度的

definition: adjective: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
example: The student undermined the teacher’s authority by questioning the teacher’s judgment on numerous occasions.
translations: vt. 破坏，渐渐破坏；挖掘地基

definition: verb: give extra weight to (a communication)
example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.
translations: vt. 强调；划线于…下
n. 底线，[计] 下划线

definition: verb: to support financially
example: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.
translations: vt. 给...保险；承诺支付；签在...下
vi. 经营保险业

definition: adjective: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding; having only one meaning or interpretation and leading to only one conclusion
example: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was cafeful to make his position completely unequivocal.
translations: adj. 明确的；不含糊的

definition: adjective: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and composure
example: The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.
translations: adj. 镇定的，不慌张的

definition: adjective: uncooperative, not willing to give up information
example: The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.
translations: adj. 不愿响应的

definition: adjective: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach
example: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.
translations: adj. 无可指责的；无可怀疑的；无懈可击的；无过失的，无罪的

definition: verb: to make nervous or upset
example: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly “Magoosh-ing”, and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.
translations: vt. 使失去勇气；使身心交疲；使焦躁；使失常

definition: adjective: having never been done or known before; novel
example: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.
translations: adj. 空前的；无前例的

definition: adjective: creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression
example: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.
translations: adj. 不吸引人的；不讨人喜欢的

definition: adjective: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success
example: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.
translations: adj. 不吉利的；不顺遂的

definition: adjective: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to authority
example: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene—unless it's nap time.
translations: adj. 不守规矩的；任性的；难驾驭的

definition: adjective: without scruples or principles
example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.
translations: adj. 肆无忌惮的；寡廉鲜耻的；不讲道德的

definition: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
example: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.
translations: adj. 不适宜的；不得体的
adv. 不得体地；不适宜地

definition: adjective: very generous
example: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.
translations: adj. 慷慨的；大方的；无限制的

definition: adjective: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified
example: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.
translations: adj. （论据等）站不住脚的；不能维持的；不能租赁的；难以防守的

definition: adjective: unfavorable; inconvenient
example: Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.
translations: adj. 不幸的；麻烦的；倔强的；困难的

definition: adjective: not confined or limited
example: untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.
translations: adj. 自由自在的；无阻碍的（等于untrammelled）

definition: adjective: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).
example: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.
translations: adj. 不能独立生存的

definition: verb: to reproach; to scold
example: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"—in the end he had to upbraidthe apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.
translations: vt. 责骂；训斥

definition: adjective: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social experience
example: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophistcate spy James Bond.
translations: adj. 彬彬有礼的，温文尔雅的；都市化的

definition: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
example: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.
translations: vi. 犹豫；踌躇；摇摆

definition: adjective: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance
example: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.
translations: adj. 空的；空虚的；空洞的；无意义的

definition: verb: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict
example: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.
translations: vt. 征服；击败；克服；抑制（感情等）

definition: noun: the quality of being different
example: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to lie”.
translations: n. 变异；变化；不一致；分歧；[数] 方差

definition: adjective: highly or widely praised or boasted about
example: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.
translations: adj. 自夸的；大肆吹嘘的
v. 夸耀；吹牛（vaunt的过去分词）

definition: adjective: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.
translations: adj. 激烈的，猛烈的；热烈的

definition: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
example: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.
translations: n. 唯利是图；贪赃枉法；受贿

definition: noun: covering consisting of a thin superficial layer that hides the underlying substance
example: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.
translations: n. 外表；虚饰；饰面；胶合板的一层；薄木片
vt. 胶合；虚饰；给…镶以饰片

definition: verb: to respect deeply
example: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was veneratedamongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.
translations: vt. 崇敬，尊敬

definition: adjective: easily excused or forgiven; pardonable
example: His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious—on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.
translations: adj. 可原谅的；（罪过）轻微的；可宽恕的

definition: adjective: truthful
example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.
translations: adj. 诚实的；真实的

definition: noun: the appearance of truth
example: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.
translations: n. 逼真，貌似真实；逼真的事物

definition: adjective: truthfully, without a doubt
example: Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.
translations: adj. 真正的，名副其实的

definition: adjective: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of another
example: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can—through hundreds of intimate "tweets"—vicariously live the life of a famous person.
translations: adj. 替代的；代理的；发同感的

definition: noun: change in one’s circumstances, usually for the worse
example: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes—massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.
translations: n. 变迁；盛衰；变化无常；变迁兴衰

definition: verb: compete for something
example: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.
translations: vi. 争；竞争
vt. 使针锋相对；提出...来竞争；以...作较量
n. (Vie)人名；(英)维

definition: verb: spread negative information about
example: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.
translations: vt. 诽谤；中伤；轻视；贬低

definition: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.
translations: vt. 维护；证明…无辜；证明…正确

definition: adjective: to have a very strong desire for revenge
example: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.
translations: adj. 怀恨的；有报仇心的；惩罚的

definition: noun: an ill-tempered or violent woman
example: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago’s invective—she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.
translations: n. 泼妇；悍妇；有男子气概的女子

definition: noun: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will
example: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racism that consumed his whole life.
translations: n. 硫酸，[无化] 硫酸盐；尖刻的话
vt. 用硫酸处理；用尖刻的话伤害

definition: adjective: harsh or corrosive in tone
example: While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.
translations: adj. 硫酸的；刻薄的

definition: adjective: to criticize harshly; to berate
example: Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.
translations: vt. 谩骂；责骂

definition: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
example: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around an look at them angrily.
translations: adj. 大声叫的；喊叫的，喧嚷的

definition: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.
translations: n. 流利；健谈

definition: adjective: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto
example: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.
translations: adj. 贪婪的；贪吃的；狼吞虎咽的

definition: adjective: lacking
example: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.
translations: adj. 欠缺的；不足的；不够格的
prep. 无；缺
v. 需要（want的现在分词）；欠缺

definition: adjective: without check or limitation; showing no moral restraints to one's anger, desire, or appetites
example: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.
translations: adj. 嬉戏的；繁茂的；荒唐的；无节制的；放纵的
n. 荡妇；水性杨花的女人
vi. 放肆；嬉戏；闲荡
vt. 挥霍
n. (Wanton)人名；(英)万顿

definition: verb: to gradually increase in size or intensity
example: Her enthusiasm for the diva’s new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.
translations: n. 蜡；蜡状物
vt. 给…上蜡
vi. 月亮渐满；增大
adj. 蜡制的；似蜡的
n. (Wax)人名；(德、罗、匈、英)瓦克斯

definition: adjective: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
example: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.
translations: adj. 古怪的；异想天开的；反复无常的

definition: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
example: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.
translations: adj. 迷人的；可爱的；引人注目的

definition: noun: spirit of the times
example: Each decade has its own zeitgeist—the 1990’s was a prosperous time in which the promise of the American Dream never seemed more palpable.
translations: n. 时代思潮，时代精神
